channel.title: Turning Windows XP to Mac OSX
channel.description:
Macs come with a really pleasing look. The interface is so polished that pretty much every Windows user envy it. If you’re on a PC longing for a Mac but can’t afford it yet, here is some free software to make your Windows PC look like a Mac. Keep in mind, these visual enhancements require additional processing power. So if you have a slow system you would probably do better without them.
[b]since people like to complain and i dont like it, i will post links aha[/b]
[b][size=15pt]DOCKS[/size][/b]
[IMG]http://i37.photobucket.com/albums/e59/ziggyzack99/dock.png[/img] Desktop docks are just indispensable if you want to make your PC look like a Mac. Docks can be used to launch programs and could well replace your Windows taskbar. - [url=http://www.stardock.com/products/ObjectDock/downloads.asp]http://www.stardock.com/products/ObjectDock/downloads.asp[/url]
[b][size=15pt]WIDGETS[/size][/b]
[IMG]http://i421.photobucket.com/albums/pp294/maugeri23/yahoo-widgets-xp-to-mac.jpg[/img]
Widgets are little objects that lie on your screen and do tiny tasks such as fetching weather data, displaying system statistics, showing time, etc. - [url=http://widgets.yahoo.com/]http://widgets.yahoo.com/[/url]
To mimic the OS X Dashboard, you can try the Yahoo! Widget Engine and get lots of widgets on to your desktop (check their widget gallery here). MakeUseOf has its own widget as well. Or you could get Google Desktop which doubles as a desktop search engine. The former is a bit cooler and slicker. Some more alternatives can be found in 6 widget platforms for your PC
[b][size=15pt]TOOLBAR ICONS[/size][/b]
[IMG]http://i421.photobucket.com/albums/pp294/maugeri23/yztoolbar_like_mac_thumb.jpg[/img]
To decorate Windows Explorer with Mac-like toolbar icons, you can download and install Y’z Toolbar software from Google. Then, get the skin for Y’z Toolbar. Windows Explorer icons now resemble that of a Mac. - [url=http://www.winmatrix.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=1161]http://www.winmatrix.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=1161[/url]
[b][size=15pt]DROP SHADOW[/size][/b]
[IMG]http://i421.photobucket.com/albums/pp294/maugeri23/yahoo-widgets-xp-to-mac.jpg[/img]
Use Y’z Shadow to add drop shadow effects to Window borders. Y’z Shadow can also make menus transparent. You can, of course, specify the thickness of the shadow by using the parameters in the Y’z Shadow settings. - [url=http://www.winmatrix.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=1161]http://www.winmatrix.com/forums/index.php?showtopic=1161[/url]
[b][size=15pt]FLYAKITEOSX[/size][/b]
[IMG]http://i421.photobucket.com/albums/pp294/maugeri23/flyakiteOSX-pack.jpg[/img]
This is an all-in-one transformation pack that applies a lot of changes to the Windows shell. It adds plenty of eye-candy to make Windows look like a Mac. Boot Screen, Login Screen, Wallpapers, Screensavers, Sound effects are all altered to mimic a Mac Desktop. If you’re looking for an all-in-one pack, FlyakiteOSX is the way to go. - http://osx.portraitofakite.com/
[b][size=15pt]FIREFOX THEMES[/size][/b]
[IMG]http://i421.photobucket.com/albums/pp294/maugeri23/macfox-firefox-theme.png[/img]
There are quite a number of themes available for Firefox that make it look like Safari. Here’s the list: iFox Smooth, iFox Metal, Macfox II, Macfox II Graphite, Cobalt Firefox. Or you can just download them from Apples website. - [url=https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/1830]https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/1830[/url]
[b][size=15pt]ICONS[/size][/b]
[IMG]http://i421.photobucket.com/albums/pp294/maugeri23/icons.jpg[/img]
Mac has an amazing set of visually pleasing icons that are really very pro-looking. You can grab the icons from here [url=http://www.osx-e.com/downloads/icons/1000_pngs.html]http://www.osx-e.com/downloads/icons/1000_pngs.html[/url]
[b][size=15pt]GET ITUNES[/size][/b]
[IMG]http://i934.photobucket.com/albums/ad187/lalaland_9696/singaporeitunesmain.jpg[/img]
iTunes is the default music management software for the Mac. Although it’s quite heavy on system resources, it comes with a nice Mac-ish look. Plus it has a number of really cool third party addons. - [url=http://www.apple.com/itunes/download/]http://www.apple.com/itunes/download/[/url]
[b]CREDITS GO TO - Shanker Ganesh a 16 year old blogger from india [/b]

item.title: Turning Windows XP to Mac OSX
item.dc:creator: @Unlimited1 .Unlimited
item.description:
@Unlimited1 wrote:

[quote=“Elijah, post:30, topic:289615”]Never did I say that, I said running Windows Xp/apps on a Mac, not the Mac OS. Those are two different things. He said he uses a Macbook for 9 months out of the year, and that he felt restricted. My rebuttal was that he can use Windows, Linux, and Mac OS. All very simply with the preinstalled Bootcamp.

I included Crossover and Parallels, because you can use those to run Windows Applications.[/quote]

Because I can’t use those things. (Bootcamp ect) As I said mac is good for somethings but gaming with one button doesn’t seem like much fun. (Yes I know you could buy a wireless mouse but whats the fun in that?)

Read full topic
item.source: Turning Windows XP to Mac OSX

item.title: Turning Windows XP to Mac OSX
item.dc:creator: @Man_UTD_Freak Man UTD Freak
item.description:
@Man_UTD_Freak wrote:

[quote=".Unlimited, post:23, topic:289615"][quote author=Elijah link=topic=382814.msg2877097#msg2877097 date=1248114574]
If you knock the Mac, please tell me how long you’ve actually used one. If you haven’t gotten past the Learning Curve, then you don’t have the right to speak
[/quote]

I use a macbook for 9 months out of each year and the only reason I have to use it is because of school. Yes there may be SOME good things about them but other wise you can do a lot more on windows and/or linux.[/quote]

I use a Mac Book for around the same amount of time each year due to school and I think that they are much easier to use and handle. I mean sure you can do a lot more on Windows or Linux but regarding daily use I feel that the Mac OS X is much easier to use and handle in comparison to Windows, Linux and other operating systems.

Read full topic

item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

Directories are different from XP, not from Vista. Instead of the folders for pictures, videos, music being stored in the documents folder, they’re in the User folder. Which is identical to Linux and Mac.

item.source: Turning Windows XP to Mac OSX

item.title: Turning Windows XP to Mac OSX
item.dc:creator: @T41 t4
item.description:
@T41 wrote:

[quote=“Elijah, post:17, topic:289615”][quote author=Mopman link=topic=382814.msg2877127#msg2877127 date=1248115670]

If you knock the Mac, please tell me how long you’ve actually used one. If you haven’t gotten past the Learning Curve, then you don’t have the right to speak

Actually, yes I do. I said Windows 7 looks better. Which it does. I don’t have to use it to see that.
[/quote]

That’s different, I said if you knock it. I don’t care what your opinion of it is. If you like Windows better than Mac, than that’s your preference. Personally, I feel that Windows has tried to integrate some of the Mac/Linux innovation into their OS. And has failed at it greatly, just because it looks better doesn’t mean it performs better, for example Vista.

I liked using Windows 7, it’s new Launchbar was very similar to the Mac OS Dock. Having applications using just icons, and minimizing to icons. It’s gadgets, take from the Mac OS widgets. It’s new directories are similar to that of the Mac OS directory layout.

All of these changes have been made because this way is better than the old way. And who came up with these innovations? Apple. Sure you can attribute some of it to Linux as well, which Linux rightly deserves it. But nonetheless, Apple came up with most of what windows has now, first.[/quote]
I will admit, because it’s painfully obvious, that Windows OSs > XP copy heavily off of Mac mindset.

Read full topic
item.source: Turning Windows XP to Mac OSX

item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:16, topic:289615”][quote author=Elijah link=topic=382814.msg2877097#msg2877097 date=1248114574]
If you knock the Mac, please tell me how long you’ve actually used one. If you haven’t gotten past the Learning Curve, then you don’t have the right to speak
[/quote]

Actually, yes I do. I said Windows 7 looks better. Which it does. I don’t have to use it to see that.[/quote]

That’s different, I said if you knock it. I don’t care what your opinion of it is. If you like Windows better than Mac, than that’s your preference. Personally, I feel that Windows has tried to integrate some of the Mac/Linux innovation into their OS. And has failed at it greatly, just because it looks better doesn’t mean it performs better, for example Vista.

I liked using Windows 7, it’s new Launchbar was very similar to the Mac OS Dock. Having applications using just icons, and minimizing to icons. It’s gadgets, take from the Mac OS widgets. It’s new directories are similar to that of the Mac OS directory layout.

All of these changes have been made because this way is better than the old way. And who came up with these innovations? Apple. Sure you can attribute some of it to Linux as well, which Linux rightly deserves it. But nonetheless, Apple came up with most of what windows has now, first.

Read full topic

item.source: Turning Windows XP to Mac OSX

item.title: Turning Windows XP to Mac OSX
item.dc:creator: @ThAt0n36Uy Elijah
item.description:
@ThAt0n36Uy wrote:

I have to disagree with all of you. I find the Mac OS to be much better than windows. All of the OS’s have their certain areas that draw people. Mac OS just happens to have more than Windows for me.

Sure Linux is free, it has 1,000’s of free packages, it’s fully customizable, etc. I mean, the Mac OS obviously doesn’t have a Package Manager, or the free software, and isn’t customizable to the extent that Linux has gone. But it has a simple intuitive interface, that is fast paced for everyday tasks.

The tools that come standard in the Mac OS make everything easier and faster. For instance the Menu bar, there’s a whole theory behind it. If you’ve ever heard of Fitt’s Law, this is why it is so much better than any other Menu Bar. The Hotkeys (which Linux has, but not on the scale that the Mac OS has.) is uniform throughout all applications. There’s also Mouse Gestures that are standard. There’s complete DnD throughout the whole OS. The Dock, don’t even get me started about the Dock. An icon of the Mac OS, don’t tell me you haven’t installed AWN, or RocketDock. It came from NeXTStep, the precursor to Mac OS X. All of this is bundled with award winning applications, and placed into a brilliantly designed Desktop.

If you knock the Mac, please tell me how long you’ve actually used one. If you haven’t gotten past the Learning Curve, then you don’t have the right to speak.

p.s. ipod is win

Read full topic
item.source: Turning Windows XP to Mac OSX
